title: Synthetic Recap
body:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. — On a night that belonged to one man, Glen Rice transformed the hardwood into his personal stage. In a 1998 clash against the Cleveland Cavaliers, Rice delivered a performance for the ages, pouring in a game-high 42 points to single-handedly power the Charlotte Hornets to a 96-88 victory.

From the opening tip, Rice was uncontainable. His shot, a picture of pure, high-arcing perfection, splashed through the net from every conceivable angle. The Cavaliers tried everything—different defenders, tighter close-outs—but nothing could cool his incendiary rhythm. Each basket was a hammer blow, each three-pointer a demoralizing dagger that chipped away at Cleveland’s resolve and ignited the home crowd.

While Rice’s offensive explosion provided the fire, the Hornets’ defense provided the final, crucial lock. Leading the charge was Anthony Mason, whose monstrous 19-rebound, 7-assist night embodied the grit required to secure such a historic win. He fought for every loose ball and anchored the paint, ensuring Rice’s heroics would not be in vain. Vlade Divac complemented the effort with a solid 14-point, 10-rebound double-double, forming an iron backbone for the surging Hornets.

For Cleveland, Shawn Kemp’s 22 points and 11 rebounds were a noble effort, but they were ultimately a footnote in the story of the night. The Cavaliers simply had no answer for the force of nature wearing purple and teal.

In the end, this was not merely a game in the standings; it was a coronation. Glen Rice’s 42-point masterpiece was a breathtaking display of scoring genius, a performance so dominant it etched his name into the memory of every fan who witnessed it and carried his team to a hard-fought triumph.
